body: @michaelmior , is it ok if I have a look at it this weekend?
Absolutely :)
LGTM
Closing this. Please open a JIRA issue if you think there is a bug.
What if the inputs of union have different column aliases? The union's output column names are expected to be the same with its first child.
Thanks @love1693294577 for reporting this, you may also need to fire a JIRA issue to trace this problem, the JIRA issues is a better choice for tracing discussions.

> the JIRA issues is a better choice for tracing discussions

How to submit, I have not found it for a long time.
@love1693294577  Please see this page https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/CALCITE/issues
I am closing this since @julianhyde seems to have already a fix.

@XuQianJin-Stars, Please don't force push. It's difficult to tell which issues you have addressed. Add commits.

Note that I questioned why there was an extra `min` function, and 4 days later @hsyuan noticed the same problem.

I'm going to repeat my earlier suggestion, in case it was missed:

>I think it might be better if RelBuilder is responsible for turning DISTINCT off. Meanwhile AggregateCall should throw if AggregateCall.distinct is true and getDistinctOptionality() is not OPTIONAL.

This would simplify a lot of things. We simply wouldn't allow people to create an AggregateCall to MIN with distinct=true. If they use RelBuilder, they get this automatically; otherwise they have to turn off distinct before they create AggregateCall. It's consistent with how we do things elsewhere - be very strict about types etc. in RelNode/RexNode land.

@hsyuan 
Thanks for looking into this ~
After this change -- https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1310 , there's no strict column name checking but only column count and column type checking (`SubstitutionVisitor::rowTypesAreEquivalent`).
Do you think there's strong need to keep the column name same during materialization matching?
There is already a issue CALCITE-3165 for the `Project`, do we really need to do this for `CALC` ?

Well, I'm not sure.
As long as Calcite provides such a method -- `Calc#accept(RexShuttle shuttle)`. It might make sense to make it work properly.
@rubenada What do you think about this patch ?
@jinxing64 @danny0405 I think we should be consistent and have the same behavior in Project and Calc, so if we already identified and fixed this issue on Project, I'm +1 on fixing it on Calc too.
@julianhyde I addressed your comments. Thanks!
@xndai @hsyuan thank for your review. I added an extra test to cover the change.

Could you please leave more comments? and it's great if there's chance this patch can be merged.

- For integers: `BYTE` to `BIGINT`)
- For fractional: `REAL`, `FLOAT`, `DOUBLE`
- For decimal: `DECIMAL`s

Hi @danny0405 , thanks for participation in review. I divided refactoring and changes into 2 commits, and I'll prepare code review changes commit soon.
@vvysotskyi , @danny0405  please take another look at the PR. I made 3 different commits, with changes, refactoring and code review updates.

I'm "meh" on the javadoc for all the `decorrelateRel` methods. The methods are called via reflective dispatch so they all do the same thing. Adding javadoc doesn't add any information content.

Don't put ' );' on a new line. We don't format code that way.

Please add commits, don't amend or squash. It's difficult to review when you squash each time. (Some reviewers ask for squash and rebase. I guess I disagree with those reviewers. I'm happy to squash and rebase when I merge your PR.)

I think you need to change algebra.md. 

I hate code formatted like this:

```
        RelNode distinct = relBuilder.push(newInput).projectNamed(
            positions.stream().map(i -> relBuilder.getRexBuilder()
                .makeInputRef(newInput, i)).collect(Collectors.toList()),
            positions.stream().map(fieldNames::get).collect(Collectors.toList()),
            false)
             .distinct()
             .build();
```

Breaking the line at the line length limit seems to me like passive-aggressive adherence to the line length policy. Isn't this more readable?

```
        RelNode distinct = relBuilder.push(newInput)
            .projectNamed(positions.stream()
                    .map(i ->
                        relBuilder.getRexBuilder().makeInputRef(newInput, i))
                    .collect(Collectors.toList()),
                positions.stream().map(fieldNames::get).collect(Collectors.toList()),
                false)
            .distinct()
            .build();
```

That said, wouldn't 
```
        RelNode distinct = relBuilder.push(newInput)
            .project(relBuilder.fields(positions))
            .distinct()
            .build();
```
do the same thing?
@julianhyde this should be ready to review whenever
I agree that Javadoc on each decorrelateRel function doesn't give much information(I guess this would be also true for trimFields functions). I updated javadoc and fixed some code style. Thanks.

@hsyuan 
Thanks for approve !

Thanks @hsyuan for review this ~
I refined by your comments and squashed the commits :)
Thanks for approve ~

> This is a large contribution, thanks for your effort. My only concern is that should we provide the option of implicit cast strategy or dialect? Different databases has some different cast strategy. like '9'/2, PostgreSQL will cast '9' to integer, which returns 4, while Hive may cast '9' to decimal, which returns 4.5. The current implementation will break many Postgres queries, and generate wrong results.

I think we can, because the `TypeCoercion` can see the `SqlValidator` then the `SqlConformance`, but i can not find a conformance of POSTGRES now. There are 2 choices:
1. Add a conformance for `POSTGRE`
2. disable the whole type coercion when doing `POSTGRE` query

It seems that only PostgreSQL has this behavior so i choose 1 and add use the conformance to control the behavior.
Thanks so much for the review @hsyuan , i'm preparing for the design doc, which should be in front of the PR first, sorry for that, the doc is ready soon.

I agree with Haisheng that we should fix getMapping() instead. If you also believe getMapping() behavior is incorrect we should just fix this function. Also getPartialMapping() is different than getMapping(). It allows non RexInputRef. I am not sure if it's OK to use getPartialMapping() here in the ProjectTableScanRule.

And I also want mention a question here:
If I want to add a MV matching rule, where is the proper place, SubstitutionVisitor or MaterializedViewSubstitutionVisitor ? what is the criterion ?

cc @hsyuan 
It'd be great if you can take a quick look at this when you have time.
Thanks  a lot :)
Hello @danny0405 , I've answered your last comments. Should I do some changes or PR can be merged ?

> Can we please add a few more test cases:

This exception only happens when aggregate is simplified to specific project. Besides,  'select id, id from src' would throw an exception if you call `project#getMapping`.  Namely, they have the same root cause. So I don't think your proposed case would make a difference.

> integeralTypes, fractionalTypes, dateSecondIntervalType, varchar10Type in `TypeCoercionTest` are not used.
> select '9'/2 returns integer 4 for Postgres, but in the POSTGRESQL_11 conformance, it still returns double.

Thanks, i have remove the useless types in TypeCoercionTest. Also add an issue and TODO [CALCITE-3269](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-3269) for PostgreSQL.

hi @julianhyde , this PR is to ensure we purge meta data cache when trace is enabled, same as when trace is disabled. CALCITE-2018 is to fix issue during propogateCostImprovement(). @vvysotskyi  also agrees they are two different issues. More details please refer to the Jira. Thanks.
Thanks @xy2953396112, but this change is too small to form a PR, maybe we can merge this change into another bigger one ~
Thanks for merging !
@danny0405 Maybe we can merge this with https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1393
Personally, I don't think a PR can't be too small :-)

@julianhyde Thank you for the comments. I have applied point 1 & 3 to the javadoc. 
Regarding point 2 since the method is quite long and complicated I believe starting with naming the algorithm makes the rest of the javadoc clearer. This is also done in many methods of EnumerableDefaults (hashJoin etc.).

Thanks @DonnyZone! I want to include this PR in the next release but unfortunately I don't think I will have time to review it this week. If somebody else manages to have a look it would be great otherwise I will do my best to review it next week.

I still think you should follow standard method javadoc formula. Describe what the method DOES not what it IS. If the method feels more like a noun than a verb that is telling you something, right...?

The only exception I could find is the `hashJoin_` method, which is private and furthermore named to indicate that it is low-level implementation. Whereas your method is public.
Yes, better to merge them.
@danny0405 How do you think merge them?
Thanks for reviewing. @hsyuan

@hsyuan

@hsyuan 
Thanks for your kind reminder.

Actually I think this case can be covered by https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1384
The matching pattern proposed in this PR is like below:
```
   query:   Project(projects: [$0, *(2, $1)])
                   Aggregate(groupSet: {0}, groupSets: [{0}], calls: [SUM($1)])
                     Scan(table: [hr, emps])
    target:  Project(projects: [$0, *(2, $1), *(2, $2)])
                   Aggregate(groupSet: {0}, groupSets: [{0}], calls: [SUM($1), COUNT()])
                     Scan(table: [hr, emps])
```
The matching pattern proposed in https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1384 is like below:
```
 query:   Project(projects: [$0, +($1, 2)])
                 Project(projects: [$1, $3, $4])
                    Rel-A
 target:  Project(projects: [$1, +($3, 2)])
                 Rel-A
```

I think the second pattern is more general and I added the test case in this PR to https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1384
How do you think ? Which one is preferred ?

If  https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1384 makes sense, it's great if you can shepherd and take a review when you have time. Then I will close this PR.

Thanks ~

Jin

@hsyuan , I'm not sure we can do that, since this change affects just EnumerableHashJoin (which will support now non-equi conditions); but there is still EnumerableMergeJoin (which only works with equi conditions) that remains unchanged.
Also, I just noticed that an EnumerableHashJoin of type SEMI/ANTI supports only equi-join.

With this PR you shouldn't see error message like "RelSubset doesn't contain its best node", which indeed is the case. But there are still a bunch of failures related to "rel has lower cost than best cost..." which will be taken care by CALCITE-2018. So it looks like I can not just enable isValid() under assert before we completely fix all these issues.
For the title, we usually don't use `Fix bug`, just describe the issue or bug concisely in the title.
